events.event_description: The Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore collapsed, causing coal export shipments from the port's two coal-loading terminals to stop for almost two months.
events.citation: Shipments from the port's two coal-loading terminals had stopped for almost two months following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26.

events.event_description: The main shipping channel into the Port of Baltimore reopened, allowing coal export operations to resume.
events.citation: The main shipping channel into the Port of Baltimore reopened on May 21.

events.event_description: Coal exports from Baltimore hit record levels of 2.9 million short tons as terminals worked through their backlog of vessels.
events.citation: In June, coal loadings for export soared to 2.9 million short tons, the most in the U.S. Census Bureau data series—which starts in 2000—as terminals worked through their backlog of vessels.

events.event_description: Port of Baltimore achieved a five-year high in coal exports, totaling 28 million short tons.
events.citation: In 2023, the Port of Baltimore set a five-year high, with coal exports totaling 28 million short tons.
